title: How to identify my strengths and weaknesses - Quora

response.answer_text: 1. First, create two lists Before you use any outside sources to help identify your strengths and weaknesses, I’d recommend that you spend about 30 minutes alone creating two lists. Your first list is going to be centered on your business or entrepreneurship goals. Call it something like, “Skills Needed to Succeed.” Don’t worry about whether you’ve thought of every possible skill required for your business to succeed. This is meant to be an overview, and is fairly general. Depending on your business, it might list things like, “an understanding of the market,” “business development,” “website development,” or “product expertise.” Once you’ve completed your list, highlight the skills that you already have, and put a star next to the ones you think you’ll need to develop. Then, set this list aside—you’ll come back to it later. The next list you’re going to create requires you to be completely honest about yourself. You can create two columns, one called “Strengths” and the other called “Weaknesses.” Depending on your personality, you’ll find one of these columns a lot easier to fill out. I can only encourage you by suggesting that you do your best to be objective. Don’t beat yourself up over what you think are major flaws, and don’t overestimate how great your strengths are. Just write them down, and move on. You also don’t need to have a comprehensive list of 100 strengths and weaknesses. If you’ve included more than 10-15 items in each column, then you’re probably starting to focus too much on strengths and weaknesses that aren’t that significant. Examples of what you might add to this list range from aspects of your character, like “calm under pressure” or “achievement-driven,” to technical skills you may have, like “HTML expertise” or “project management experience.” The purpose of this list will be to start off with some general ideas that you have about yourself, and then get input from other sources to help you refine your list. To help you think about what to include in your strengths and weaknesses, try asking yourself questions like: What am I good at?What have others complimented me about?What have others had to help me with on more than one occasion?Which projects and tasks seem to drain my energy?Which projects have I spent hours on without getting tired?What are my hobbies, and why do I like doing them?After you’ve spent some time honestly assessing your strengths and weaknesses, it’s time to get input from those closest to you: a significant other, your mentor, close friends, or family members. 2. Talk to people you trust The problem with using a list of strengths and weaknesses that only you’ve completed is that you have a biased opinion of yourself. Most people think too highly of themselves, or too little of themselves. If you’re like me, then you somehow manage to do both at the same time. We all need some kind of “sounding board” to help us gain clarity and get closer to the truth about ourselves. That’s where other people come in handy. Try thinking of three to five people whose opinions you trust, and who have had the chance to live or work with you for an extended period of time. You want people who have observed your behavior and character in a number of different situations. For most people, that group will include a significant other, perhaps a mentor or advisor, a best friend, one or more siblings, or your parent(s). The length of your relationships isn’t the only thing to consider. The most important thing is whether or not you value or trust their opinion of you. Some friends and family members will be too biased—they either think everything you do is amazing, or their opinions have been hurtful and destructive in the past. Carefully select people who have a good track record of being balanced and helpful, even when they’ve needed to tell you something that you didn’t want to hear. Once you’ve got a group of people selected, reach out to them. You can go out to coffee with each of them, or simply send an email with some questions and ask for their honest feedback. When you reach out to them, make sure you give some context as to why you’re asking for their opinion. Tell them that you want to start a business, and that in order to be successful, you’re trying to take stock of your strengths and weaknesses. Ask them what it is about you that they think will contribute to your success. Then, ask them to tell you the weaknesses you have that may cause you to fail. As you receive feedback, start adding more details to your two lists. You’ll start to see that some of the strengths and weaknesses you listed are confirmed by those you trust, while others that you listed aren’t as significant to the people who have spent time with you. Refine your lists. 3. Take a personality test In addition to the time you’ve spent thinking about yourself and the opinions you’ve gathered from others, personality tests are another useful resource to help you identify strengths and weaknesses. 4. Try new things One problem with identifying strengths and weaknesses comes when you have a lack of experience. In some cases, you might look at your list of weaknesses and notice that it mostly boils down to “I don’t know, I’ve never tried.” For instance, how do you know if you have an athletic or artistic ability if you’ve never tried to do something athletic or artistic? I’m a big believer in pushing yourself to grow by doing things you’ve never done before. To be honest, if you’re reluctant to try new things, then here’s your instant personality test result: don’t be an entrepreneur. Evaluating your lists Now that you’ve spent some time identifying your strengths and weaknesses, you can evaluate which ones need some additional attention from you. Some of your strengths represent the absolute best you have to offer right now. Other strengths may need to be further developed before they can be used to their fullest potential. Finally, some strengths likely won’t be integral to your success. In your “weaknesses” column, some weaknesses will be glaring. You will need to address them and improve upon them before you’ll be able to succeed. Other weaknesses, like some of your strengths, may simply be irrelevant to your overall business objectives. Finally, some weaknesses may be important, but maybe you’re not the one to overcome them. In order to understand what I mean, we need to talk about opportunity cost.

I found really great article about how you can identify your strengths and weaknesses.  So here you have it. First thing, you need to understand is your abilities 1. Appreciate your effort. You should take a good look at where you are already strong and where you could stand some improvement. Give your awesome self a pat on the back and remember that you are an amazing person. 2. Write down what you do. Spend some time ( a few days or week) writing down all of the activities you do throughou  a day. Rate them from one to five, depending upon how much you enjoy doing or participating in them. 3. Think about your values. Sometimes, it can be difficult to identify our strengths and weaknesses because we haven't taken the time to clarify our core values.  Here are some great questions to ask yourself: Think about a few people you respect. What do you admire about them? What traits do they possess that you value? How do you see these in your own life? Imagine you could change one thing about your community. What would it be?Why? What do you think that shows about what's most important to you? Remember a moment in your life where you felt very satisfied or fulfilled. What was that moment? What happened? Who were you with? Why did you feel that way? Imagine that your house is on fire (but all pets and people are safe) and you can save just 3 objects. What would you save, and why? 4. Examine your responses for themes and patterns. Once you've reflected on your values, examine the responses for things that may repeat. For example, perhaps you admire Bill Gates and Richard Branson for their entrepreneurial spirit and creativity. This suggests that you may value Ambition, Competition, and Ingenuity.  5. Determine whether your life aligns with your values. Sometimes, we may feel like we have a weakness in a particular area when our lives don't align with our core values, for whatever reason.  For example, perhaps you value Ambition and Competition, but you feel stuck at a dead-end job where you're never challenged or given an opportunity to prove yourself. You might feel that you have a weakness in this area because your life isn't currently aligned with what's very important to you. 6. Consider situational meanings. Think about what constitute strengths or weaknesses relative to the social conventions or customs withinyour local context. Knowing how these differ depending on where you live canhelp you determine what might be seen as a strength or weakness in thatparticular geographic location.  For example, if you live in a  area where everyone works with their hands, the members of this community will likely value attributes related to physical labor and working long hours during the day. If you happen to live in a large city, however, these attributes might not appear as important, unless you happen to work some other manual labor job. So to understand your abilities you need to : appreciate your effort, write down what you do, think about your value, Examine your responses for themes and patterns,  Determine whether your life aligns with your values and Consider situational meanings. Second thing, you need perform a reflective best self exercise 1. Find people to ask. To help you figure out what your strengths and weaknesses are, you can do a Reflective Best Self (RBS) exercise. This helps you figure out what others think about you in order to help you find yourstrengths. To start, think of people in every aspect of your life. 2. Ask for feedback. Once you've chosen your candidate, send them ane-mail asking them about your strengths. Ask them to give you particular instances where they saw you use these strengths. Make sure to mention that these strengths can be skill-based or personality -based. Both kinds of responses are important. 3. Look for commonalities. Once you receive all the results,you need to look for things that are similar in them. Read through each response and think about what it means. Try to pull out what traits each person is pointing, and read the specific instance to see if any other traits arise. After you interpret them all, compare them to one another and find similar traits that many people mention. 4. Make a self-portrait. Once you have all the results, write a self-portrait analysis of your strengths. Make sure to incorporate all the different aspects that people pinpointed in their discussion of you and any traits you brought out in your own analysis. It reminds you of the characteristics you use when you are at your best and can help lead your future actions on how to strive touse them more.  To perform a reflective self exercise you need to : Find people to ask,  Ask for feedback, Look for commonalities and Make a self-portrait. Third thing, you need to list is your actions 1. Write about your actions. Consider how you respond in certain situations that require action, thought, and insight.  The reason for doing this is that the spontaneous reactions tell you a lot about how you react in both ordinary and intense situations. You can write them down to help you decipher your actions and abilities.   2. Think of a challenging situation in which something bad happened. Perhaps it's being in a car crash or a child suddenly dashing out in front of your car while you slam on your brakes. How did you react when confronted with the spontaneous situation? Did you clam up and retreat or did you meet the challenge head on, assembling tools and resources to address the situation? If you took control and acted as a leader, you probably feel that courage and being able to handle these situations is a strength. If you reacted by crying uncontrollably, feeling helpless or lashing out at others, staying inself-control during a challenging situation might be a weakness.   Make sure to consider things from several angles.  3. Find a less challenging situation. Think about a time when you faced a hard decision but one that wasn't so life and death. For example, how do you react when you enter a crowded room? Do you want to engage everyone you meet there or do you want to find a quiet corner away from the noise and connect with just one person? 4. Consider times you faced a difficult personal situation. Think of a timewhen you've been put on the spot and had to react immediately. How quickly did you learn and adapt to new situations? Are you a fast thinker, rattling off agreat comeback when a co-worker makes a snide remark? Or do you tend to absorb, think, and then react in those situations? Remember that any strength you might have developed can sometimes have tradeoffs. If you spend most of your life alone reading and writing, for example, you might not be as apt at small talk as other people, but you will probably have a knack for finding the plot of a book and discussing deep topics with others. You also may grown up with younger siblings, which means you maybe compassionate, patient, and good at diffusing situations. It’s important to keep in mind that the world needs many different people with different types of strengths and interests in order to be as diverse as it is. You don’t necessarily need to be good at everything, just at what you consider important for yourself. To know your actions: Write them down, Think of a challenging situation in which something bad happened, Find a less challenging situation and Consider times you faced a difficult personal situation. Fourth thing, you need to list is your desires 1. Ask yourself about your desires. Your desires say a lot about you, even if you've been spending a lot of time denying them. Consider why you want to complete those activities or goals and what it will take toreach them.  Many people fall into the trap of doing what their families want and becoming a doctor or lawyer when they'd rather have been a ballet dancer or a mountain trekker instead. Ask yourself, "What are my desires in life?" Whether you're applying for your first job or have just settled into retirement, you should always have goals and yearnings in life. Determine what drives you and what makes you happy. 2. Decide what you enjoy. Begin to ask yourself about the things you most enjoy in life. Write down the answers to the question,"What types of activities do I find satisfying or appealing?" For some people, sitting by the fire with their Labrador Retriever by their side sis extremely satisfying. For others, they’d rather be rock climbing or taking aroad trip. 3. Consider what motivates you. Along with your desires, you need to decide what keeps you motivated in life. Write down your answers to the question, "When do I feel energized and motivated?"Consider times in your life when you feel ready to take the world on by storm or inspired to go to the next level. The areas that inspire and motivate you are typically where you are strongest. To know about your desires: Ask yourself about them, Decide what you enjoy, Consider what motivates you. Fifth thing: Assessing Your Strengths and Weaknesses 1. Rethink your weaknesses. "Weakness" isn't the most helpful way to think about areas for development. In reality, people really aren’t weak, even though we might really feel or think this way at times. However, most people feel that they could be stronger in certain areas in their lives, their skill sets, and other areas. Since they feel they are not as strong in those areas, it’s common to assign the opposite to describe when we feel we need to work on an area to feel stronger and competent. Instead of focusing on "weakness," which has a negative feel to it, think about your areas for growth or improvement - this keeps you focused on the future and what you can do to get better. Weaknesses could be conceived as something about yourself that you either have the power to improve, in so far as they are at all related to your desires, or are perhaps simply not relevant to your desires or goals in life whatsoever. Acknowledging either one is acceptable. Weaknesses are not permanent aspects of ourselves, but instead are changeable aspects of how we do things so we can become even more excellent. 2. Identify your areas for growth. Areas in which you can develop might be related to anything, including certain professional or social skills or poor self-restraint with food. You could also simply refer to an inability to catch a baseball or perform math equations quickly. Often times, areas forgrowth are framed in terms of "learning lessons from life" and notrepeating mistakes. Other times, it's about making the effort to overcome alack of skills you perceive in yourself. 3. Focus on your strengths. Some might consider focusing on personal weaknesses at all as waste of time, or even a mis-framing of the issues. Instead, focus primarily on your strengths and try to cultivate these whenever possible.  For example, if you want to work on becoming more assertive, first start with what assertiveness skills you feel you’re already doing. Maybe you have trouble saying no, but instead you have the ability to state your intentions in a way where your intention is understood and you can spare the feelings of the person.  4. Write down your strengths and weaknesses. Once you assess all you've written down about your actions and desires, it's time to focus on what you think your strengths and weaknesses are. Using the lists from other people you got earlier and that you have learned about yourself through the other exercises, write down areas of your work and life that you think are your strong and weak areas. Focus on how you currently see your own strengths and weaknesses based on what you're doing in your life right now, both personal and professional, rather than looking to the past or to your desires. 5. Compare the lists against one another. Did they match up and did you findany surprises? Did you think you were strong in one area but in your actions list that doesn’t appear to be the case? This type of mismatch occurs when you're telling yourself you're one way, but a challenging situation displays your real character instead. 6. Consider any surprises or mismatches. Look at the different lists you'vemade. Look for any surprises or places that don't match up. Reflect on why you think that some of the qualities and weaknesses you've spotted have turned outto be different. Is it possible that you think you enjoy certain things or that you're motivated by certain things, but in actuality you can't or you aren’t? These lists will help you see that. Focus on those areas that differ and try to identify situations that address the area. For example, did you write that you aspire to become asinger, but on your lists of believed strengths, you said that you were good atscience or medicine? While a singing doctor might be a novelty, the two professions differ considerably. Figure out which area really motivates you inthe long-term. 7. Ask the opinions of friends or family. Have a close friend or family member provide you with constructive feedback. Although self examination can lead you to a few answers, getting an outside opinion will help you either solidify your observations or can shatter a few illusions as well. Learning how to receive constructive feedback from others is essential to being part of acommunity. It is important not to get defensive, or take it as a personal attack, simply because someone suggests an area of improvement. Learning toincorporate constructive feedback from others into your everyday life can be astrength in itself. If you don't think that a family member can be honest, choose someone who will give you the truth and not sugar coat or gloss over your weaknesses. Findan external, neutral person, preferably a peer or a mentor, to give you honest, constructive feedback. 8. Reflect on your findings. After you assess your strengths and weaknesses, spend some time to reflect and determine how you feel about what you found. Decide if you need or want to work on any of your weaknesses and contemplate what you will need to do to attack or change these weaknesses. Enlist in a class or find activities that will address your weaknesses. For example, if you find that you become a deer in headlights when confronted with a spontaneous situation, put yourself in situations where spontaneity occurs. Examples including joining a community theater, participating on a sports team, or doing karaoke at the bar. 9. Reject perfectionism. Take care not to become hung up on your weaknesses. This pattern can quickly fall into the nonconstructive patternof perfectionism, which can actually hold you back from success. It’s better to begin with what you do well for a given skill set, then find several details to enhance those skills and slowly improve over time.   For example, you want to improve your communication skills. After someself-reflection, you decide you are actually a pretty good listener, which is your strength. However, you clam up when it’s your turn to speak, which is your weakness. You decide you want to be more verbal, so you work on interjecting maybe a sentence or two within the conversation at small pauses. 10. Don't deny important moments in your life. Everyone hasthings in their life that they excel at. There are times when you do somethingyou've never done before, but it just clicks and you find that you're a total natural at it. This might be sport, art, creative pursuits, interacting with animals, or standing in for someone who is away and doing their job. Not everyone will experience the same amazing moments as you, but when you have them, work with it to enhance your life and reach your true potential. Source: How to Identify Your Strengths and Weaknesses

I knew everyone’s secret crush and I wrote them down. I had a spiral bound notebook with that metal spiral that would poke out and scratch me whenever I carried it. It hurt. But that is the path a hard-core 11 year old journalist / spy must take. Every day I’d look around and if I saw David looking at Joanna I’d write in my book, “David likes Joanna!” I was 11. All day long I’d write down what I saw. I’d record conversations I overheard, I’d write down glances two kids would give each other. Soon everyone realized what I was doing. All the other kids wanted to see what was in my notebook. They’d start screaming at me to let them see. Finally the teacher said, “Let me see that book”. She read it. “You aren’t allowed to bring this book back into school,” she told me. Banned and censored for the first time.  At age 12 I wanted to be in the newspaper. I interviewed many politicians. I’d call up Senators, Congressmen, even the President. I interviewed the minority leader of the House. I interviewed the Chief Usher of the White House. I interviewed Governors. I interviewed Senators. I pretended to be sick so I’d stay home from school just in case someone called me back. My parents hated it. Phone calls weren’t cheap then. I ran up a $600 bill one month. Then $1100 the next. My dad yelled at me, “You are owing us back this money!” and he stopped my allowance. But then the South Brunswick Central Post paid me $150 to run some of the interviews. It wasn’t enough to pay what I owed my parents. But I didn’t really care about that.   Here’s what you do: Write down the ten things you loved doing when you were six, seven, eight, ten, 12, 14, 18, 22. I loved: WritingChessStarting businesses (I was on my fourth failed business by the time I was 27). At a young age I was obsessed with reading about Howard Hughes and the topic of “billionaires”.Politics (not the issues so much as the game of it). I loved reading about how elections were won (Hunter S. Thompson’s “Fear & Loathing on the Campaign Trail in ‘72”, Ted White’s “Making of the President” series).Investing (I was reading the Wall St Journal every day as a kid even though I knew nothing about the companies the articles were about)Computers (I tried to build one and failed).Breakdancing (yes).The occult (I wanted to learn how to astral project so I can project invisibly out of my body at night and watch girls changing their clothes).Psychology (because there were so many stories about sex, I read every pop psychology book I could find. For instance, “Don’t Say Yes When You Want to Say No”.)Advice columns. I was obsessed with reading “Dear Abbe” and “Dear Meg” and “Ann Landers” and I read all the books of the compilation of their columns.Comic books. I collected everything.All of these things I loved by the time I was 15.  How the Brain Builds Strengths The brain is always changing. Always forming new connections. But there are two times in life when the brain forms extra fast connections (sheathed by something called myelin which is sort of like saying myelin creates the paths that are hyper loops in the brain): A) when you are born. And you need to learn all those good things like eating, walking, etc. B) when you hit puberty and have to learn all the skills that are necessary to be a productive and successful member of the tribe. Your strengths are going to plant their seeds during these periods.  I was lost and looking for something to do with my life. So I wrote down the above list to try and figure out what I could do with my life. This was about 15 years ago. And then I had to figure out: what can I do with these interests now? With each item I figured out how it “aged”. For instance, with investing, I could read and learn about all the latest investing techniques and perhaps start a business in the sector. I ended up starting five businesses involving investing and writing six books about the topic. With comic books, I scripted one out, hired someone to draw it. It bombed. But that’s ok. I did it. With “the occult” I never succeeded in astral projection. But starting when I was 14 it began a life-long journey into Taoism, Buddhism, and meditation. How did this serve me as an adult? Other than the intangible ways, one of my books “The Power of No”, was published by one of the premium spiritual publishers. Breakdancing. Hey! It’s how I work out every day. It’s exhausting! Writing. I’ve now written 18 books. Working on the next and the next. I’d like to try writing a novel. Maybe that will be next. Oh, and if you are at all curious about my writing process, read this. Politics. Someone just asked me to run for a particular party for Governor of New York. Fortunately I was smart enough to say “No” (the power of NO!). Chess. I played for about an hour this morning. Chess has helped me get almost every job or opportunity I’ve ever had. More than any college degree. And Advice Columns. Well…I love writing on Quora!

Weakness is nothing to be ashamed of. But strength is no reason for pride, either. Each of us has unique strengths and weaknesses that compose who we are. But even if you already know your why, knowing your strengths and weaknesses can help you shape how to reach your goals. So rather than spinning your wheels trying to be good at everything, why not spend your time becoming great at one or two things? WHAT ARE YOU GOOD AT? What comes naturally to you that others find difficult? What are the things you’re doing when you lose track of time? These are your strengths. The opposite items would be your weaknesses: the things that you find difficult, boring, or that make you want to fast-forward so it will be over already. When you know what you’re capable of, it can help you shape your goals. Knowing your strengths and weaknesses can help you create the most effective path to reaching your vision. It can help you plan around obstacles before you reach them in order to improve your chances of success. SHOULD WE FOCUS ON STRENGTHS OR WEAKNESSES? We’ve often been told to work on our weaknesses. And while it’s never a bad thing to improve ourselves, sometimes our time is better spent focusing on our strengths.It’s basically the concept of specialization of labor. It used to be that a person had to be a jack-of-all-trades just to get by. Nowadays, we specialize. One man writes software all day, while another cleans suits all day. Then those two exchange money for the product or service that the other provides. Each one focuses on using their strengths, because the programmer wouldn’t be very good at dry cleaning, and the cleaner wouldn’t be very good at writing software. Could it get done if they switched? Maybe, but the quality will certainly be lower. Hence, we specialize. ALWAYS GIVE YOUR BEST EFFORT… WHICH SOMETIMES MEANS LETTING SOMEONE ELSE DO IT If you know you are good at something, that’s great! Do it to the best of your ability and enjoy the work. If you know you aren’t good at something, that’s okay too. It’s perfectly acceptable to hire someone else to do it for you. The time and stress you will save from having to learn to do it yourself will definitely be worth the cost. There will probably be exceptions where it makes sense for you to try to learn a new skill. But remember, it’s impossible to learn everything, especially on a professional level. The sooner you let go of the idea that you have to do everything yourself (sorry, perfectionists), the better off you’ll be. FOCUS ON YOUR STRENGTHS If you still aren’t convinced, here’s one more example. Let’s say you are a right-handed batter and you just got your big break in the major leagues. Do you decide to practice your left-handed swing because you’re not as good at it? Of course not! You work on further improving your right-handed swing, because that will give you the best chance of success. If you have no idea what your strengths are, take out a sheet of paper and try to come up with at least five things that you are good at. If you’ve never done this before, it can be difficult, since the possibilities might as well be endless. Think of what you would do with your time if money didn’t matter. Would you build things with your hands, or would you write song lyrics? If you could switch to any career you wanted, what would it be? What aspects of that career make it sound appealing? Are you good with numbers? What are the parts of your day that you look forward to? Do you enjoy giving presentations? What topics do your friends come and ask you about? Is there a trivia category that you would dominate? If you are still having trouble identifying your strengths, ask a friend or family member to tell you what they think you’re good at. You may be surprised by their answers! Once you have your list, you can keep your strengths in mind when deciding how to spend your time. For instance, if you aren’t good with numbers, you might want to hire a CPA to do your taxes for you. That way you can be intentional about the way you spend your time — your taxes will get done properly, and you will be freed up to work on your debut novel.

A lot of people misunderstand this question (it's a popular one). There is a difference between your strengths and your weaknesses IN GENERAL, and your strengths and your weaknesses in regards to your primary craft. For example: In general, here are some of my strengths and weaknesses... STRENGTHS CreativityProblem-solvingWritingStorytellingTechnologyEtc.WEAKNESSES MathScienceHistoryMultiple-choice testingEtc.When people say "focus on your strengths and not your weaknesses," I disagree. That approach only speaks to generalities. Sure, I should be a "writer" and not a "mathematician."  Got it. But then what? The key is to figure out what your strengths are and your weaknesses are in regards to your primary aim.  For example: If all you want to be a writer in today's world, it's not about ignoring everything that isn't writing—actually quite the opposite. It means realizing you'll probably have to publish independently: in which case you need to understand marketing, and cover design, and copywriting, and how you're going to promote the book on different channels, which means doing podcasts and YouTube interviews, and oh wait one of your weaknesses is public speaking because you're shy, well now you need to work on that too, etc. This whole question should be reframed: "How can I identify my strengths and weaknesses IN REGARDS TO MY PRIMARY AIM?" I know I'm terrible at multiple-choice testing. I know I'm not great at exams or memorizing anatomy or having the structure to follow an antibody science experiment from start to finish. I know these things—which is why I did not follow in my father's footsteps to become a doctor. Even with all his pushing and prodding, I actually felt like I was doing him a huge favor. Why try to be something I'm not (and have him fund it) when I'd just end up failing? Not by choice, but by discourse. That's not who I am, that's a poor use of my time, and it's a horrible investment. (You're welcome, Dad.) What is a better investment is taking what I know I want to become and putting ALL my resources into that. So then it becomes a question of: "How can I identify my strengths and my weaknesses BASED ON WHO I WANT TO BE AND WHERE I WANT TO GO." In the gym, we live by this phrase: If it hurts, it's good for you. If it hurts more, it's better. It's very easy to identify what you're already good at and what you still need to practice. How do you know? (Again, in regards to your primary aim in life...) If you look forward to doing it, chances are you're already pretty good at it.  (And again, in regards to your primary aim in life...) If you hate doing it, or find it less fun or less enjoyable, chances are you still need to work at it. In most cases, that rule holds true.

Strengths I’m really smart, I’ve been told. It means I give fairly good advice, and I can hold good conversationsI’m a pretty good researcher and writer. I also tell great stories and I’m very entertaining and creative.I’m fiercely loyal to my friends. I would do anything for those I love. Even to those I don’t know, I’m gentle. I genuinely hate seeing people in pain.I’m generous. I give great presents and I really put effort into it. I’m also helpful. I really find my day is best when I can help someone else.I’m honest with my feelings. You know where you stand with me, I don’t fake friendship.I seek help and advice, and listen to it.Weaknesses I’m deeply jealous. I want to be the best and if I’m not, I can be very upset.I am incredibly harsh on myself. Seriously, if I make a mistake, I can beat myself down for months. External criticism is even harder for me, I am overly sensitive. I cry easily, and it can be a burden to my friends.I worry too much. I always assume the worst.I can be thoughtless and a bit…silly about getting attention or my actions. It gets me into enormous trouble. Like screwing up here on Quora, or even doing stuff that risks my own life. I’m much better now.I am very awkward with people. I can be very odd in conversation. It makes getting close to me very hard.I can be incredibly lazy, if I don’t like a task. I can dig my heels and procrastinate like no other which means I’m a terrible housekeeper.

I love my ‘weaknesses,’ and here is why I don’t want to fix them, from my article — What If I Don’t Want to be Fixed? “I don’t want to be fixed. I want to use my ‘weaknesses’ to propel me to live the life that I want.” I plan what I’m not going to do, then I still do stupid things. This week I was introduced to the carnage that is ‘Pie Face.’ There is a special place reserved in hell for the creator of this device. He’s laughing at parents everywhere now. ‘Let’s have a game that involves loads of kids whacking a high striker with a hammer, that then throws whipped cream all over the living room.’ Genius! I hate you pie face man. I love it when everything is clean and tidy at home, it helps me relax. Naturally then, I hate it when it’s a shithole. If it’s a shithole maybe Donald Trump won’t let me in America. ‘Aren’t the kids enjoying themselves!’ Yes. But I’m dying inside. Must clean. Must clean. Must clean! NOW. Stupid Matt. Have some fun. I always tell myself I need to be less uptight at home. After three years of trying to teach, coerce, persuade and demand my wife and step-kids to be tidier, nothing has changed. And I’ve eventually realised – it never will. Maybe this isn’t a bad thing. Why do I want to fix them? Why do I want to fix myself so that I can be more care-free? Why do I want to write things that people can relate to so that they can fix themselves? Why are we so obsessed with self-improvement? Things I should try to fix about myself that I’m not going to dwell on as much anymore: I get angry sometimesI am anxious most daysI always worry, or think, about money, even if I’m in a secure momentI’m a bit of a hypochondriac, but not about me. I worry about those I love getting sickI work too hard, maybe, if there’s such a thingI don’t want to be fixed, so I’m not going to worry about any of this. All of these things seem negative, but to me that’s not always the case. Here’s why… Anger & Anxiety James Altucher says that anger is just fear clothed. And he’s right. I was scared Pie Face would destroy my home, so I got a bit angry. Only on the inside though, on this occasion. I can’t think of a time that fear wasn’t behind an angry moment. I got mad earlier today when a driver cut me up. I was scared that an accident might hurt me. It might cost me money. It might cost me time. Everything compounded. ARRGHH! Stupid woman. Anger can be a great fuel to my fire though. A fire of productivity, not of rage. When I see stupid people doing their normal stupid things it makes me want to change the world. It drives me to do my own stupid things that will probably make no difference to the world. This week I wanted to write a letter to the council and complain about a pedestrian crossing. But they wouldn’t have cared. That makes me a bit angry. Maybe if I become rich and famous more people would listen to me. More people would know me, so more people might think I am stupid. That sounds good. I need to work harder to get more attention. Thank you anger for the push. Money Worries Billionaires also worry about money, just differently than the rest of us. They worry about keeping wealth, while we worry about creating it, or at least being able to buy food next week. I go through cycles. I make quite a lot, then I lose or spend it all. Then I repeat this again and again. I think stability would be good, but maybe boring. I want to find out. This year I’ll be mostly being sensible and conservative. Then next year I can think about losing everything again. From bad property projects, to a stupidly expensive wedding, to my complete inability to save, I am good at finding stupid things to do with any money I make. But I wouldn’t change any of the experiences I’ve had as a result. And I’m always increasing my income streams generally. My worries and intermittent failures also help me to plan and execute my financial strategies better. They make me more conscientious. Thank you money worries for giving me my drive. Plus, money is interesting to me. Everybody, including me, says things like: ‘I don’t do it for the money’ ‘Add value to the world and money will chase you’ These things can be true, but why is it bad to do things for the money? Money will always motivate me, whether I have a little or a lot. That’s my truth and I’m not sorry for that. I love you though, that’s why all my content is free. I don’t want your money. Worrying About Getting Sick My family are mostly worriers. We worry about each other getting sick, which makes ourselves sick. Maybe this makes us all stupid, or nice, I don’t know. But what’s the point. Worrying about something that’s out of our control never makes the thing better, or less likely to happen. Please don’t worry about me family. I worry that worrying might make you sick. But hold on… Worrying about everyone getting sick makes me want to spend more time with the important people in my life, and create more happy memories. Thank you health worries for making me live life. Related article — How to Never Worry About Anything Ever Again Working Too Hard I don’t think this is a thing. Not for me anyway, I have lofty ambitions. If I’m not willing to put in the work, I don’t deserve the life that I think I want. I don’t like people who don’t work hard and think that the world owes them something. I wrote a full rant about this. I work hard because I worry about failing. If I can outwork everyone else, and do good work, then I should always be OK. I’ll never fall for the ‘work smart, not hard’ BS. Do both. You lazy bastard. But only if you want to change your life and maybe be remembered for something. If you don’t, go and sit on the sofa and binge on Netflix. I like Netflix. I would do this all day if I didn’t care so much about my future. Thank you to my parents and my influences for giving me the hunger to do something with my life. That’s Why I Don’t Want to be Fixed… I want to use all my ‘negative’ traits to learn about myself and then use them to drive the positive. To live better. To make more lasting memories. To maybe even leave a legacy. Or maybe I should worry that I just wrote an article saying that anger, anxiety and worry are all good things? That was really stupid. Maybe I’ll do it again soon. But for now… In anger and resentment, sincerely,  -Matthew Brown What are you going to achieve in 2018? Are you struggling for an idea? Or do you have THE idea, but don’t know how to pursue it? If you’ve had a strong start in business, are you now unsure of how to take it to the next level? Or, do you just want to live a more fulfilled life personally…? Well, I have great news. Our most valuable and actionable content to date is now here… I have written The Business of Life Playbook: 50 life-changing tactics to design a rich life to change your fortunes… 20 pages and 7,000+ words, split into 50 digestible sections, it is respectful of your time and your ambitions, whilst delivering punchy, actionable advice when you need it. A combination of the best personal development and entrepreneurship advice, this is your ultimate cheat-sheet to get you to the next level, personally and professionally. Available for FREE, yes that’s right, for FREE, now. Get your copy here in minutes — The Business of Life Playbook: 50 life-changing tactics to design a rich life

I can’t overemphasize how important it is to know your top strengths and top weaknesses. Knowing your top strengths gives you a filter through which you can make decision about what you will and won’t do with your time. Knowing your top weaknesses allows you to be aware of what you need to work on so that you won’t be limited. All people like knowing their strengths, but it takes a very mature person to actively seek out their weaknesses in order to improve them. While your strengths are what will make you successful, working on your top weaknesses will help you live with less stress. 1. Try a wide range of activities. Matthew Jones had a great point about trying a wide variety of activities. I would also agree with this. Make a list of things you may be good at and start finding chances to try each activity. After you’ve completed one, assess yourself and how you did. I am planning on doing this for myself soon. It will involve writing a list of about 6 things I want to try and then giving each one a certain amount of time or sessions to see how it goes. 2: Find a good personality test I’m usually pretty wary of personality tests. However, I stumbled on one that actually did help me, Jordan Peterson’s ‘present authoring program’. Jordan B Peterson is a clinical psycologist who is gaining in popularity these days. While I’ve done a handful of personality tests before, his program brought to light some of my weaknesses that I’ve never considered. There are two section to the program. One deals with your “virtues” (strengths) and one deal with your faults (weaknesses). Over a series of pages, he makes you select your top virtues and faults from various lists. Then, at the end, he makes you select the “top of the top” from all the selections you’ve made. After that, he makes you rank these final selections from most to least impactful in your life. While I had a basic idea of my strengths and weaknesses before, making me narrow the list down and then order it was a great way to force me to prioritize. From doing this program, I learned my top virtues are: Like to learn new thingsMake friends easilyDo things according to a planI somewhat knew these already but it was cool to see how I ranked them. My top faults were: feel that I’m being unproductive when I relaxseriously dislike having my routine or schedule interruptedam interested in so many things that I don’t know what to focus onThe faults were what blew my mind. I had never actually made the connection that I have a real issue with getting aggravated when my schedule gets interrupted. But after seeing it and thinking more about it, it’s spot on. I began realizing all the times that I’ve given people attitude because they messed up my plan for the day. This is something I really need to work on so I’m thankful this program helped me spot it. 3: Ask people Sometimes your strengths and weaknesses are very apparent to others but unknown to you. It’s easy for us to look at someone else and see what they are good and not so good at because we are looking at them from a third person point of view. But when we try to analyze ourselves, we let our ego and other thoughts get in the way of the truth. Find a couple people who know you, but don’t know you as well as your best friends and family. Often times, these are the people who will give you the most honest answers since they don’t have pressure to make you feel good like your best friends and family. Tell them you are working on improving yourself and looking for feedback on your top 3 strengths and weaknesses. It’s very important to tell them to be honest and that your feelings won’t get hurt (note: you must mean it!). The key to this entire process of finding your strengths and weaknesses is to drop your ego. When your ego gets in the way, your judgement gets cloudy and you don’t accept criticism. No one likes to be told what they aren’t good at, but the people who can listen to this feedback and actively work on it are the ones who will rise to the top.

Are you asking for advice on how to answer this question in the context of a job interview? If so, I believe you have no choice but honesty. Anything else will come back to bite you. So for example, let’s say you are really strong at managing projects, and you know that you are not strong in verbal communication in a group setting. You might say, “I believe my ability to manage projects is a strength that will add a lot of value to this team, and if I were to choose one area I’d like to improve on it would be presenting to groups - I get a little tongue tied there, and could improve on that with more practice.” There. You have admitted the thing that makes you most nervous, but framed it in a way that shows you are aware and willing to improve. Nothing to hide - and you have claimed the thing you do best - no false humility. This kind of candor and confident vulnerability will put you in a positive light. Those people who try to make themselves look “perfect” by falsely presenting an attractive quality as a weakness come off insincere. If you say, “I guess my flaw is that I simply work too much,” even if it is true, it comes across as inauthentic. Be genuine in sharing what you do well and where you want to grow, then you can relax and know that they hired you knowing you are not perfect.

Most people want to develop self-awareness. Whether you’re a CEO, entrepreneur, or aspiring artist, the more knowledge you have of your strengths and weaknesses, the easier life becomes. When you take a step back and can see the whole playing field, you can make adjustments. Maximizing your strengths and improving your weaknesses is the key to self growth.  Here are four ways to identify strengths and weaknesses: 1. Pause and reflect.  There’s no substitute for self-reflection. Take the time to reflect on your abilities. Contemplate the tasks and activities that come naturally to you, the things that, for some reason, you can perform well with very little effort. Recall various time periods of your life and the various interests you had. Make a list of the the things that you do well and then consider your shortcomings. Some people are more aware of their strengths, while others are more aware of their weaknesses—it’s normal to be more aware of one than the other. Spend greater time thinking about the whichever you know the least about.  2. Ask others for their input.  Get feedback from the people in your life. Instead of playing a personal guessing game, gain some certainty by asking others what they perceive to be your strengths and weaknesses. Some of what people say may surprise you, while other statements may reflect some of your internal thoughts. Either way, you’ll continue to learn and gain confirmation of your inner dialogue.  3. Engage in a wide range of activities. The only way to confirm your strengths and weakness is to put yourself in diverse situations. We rarely recognize what we’re bad at because we structure our environments in a way that minimizes or covers our strengths. Similarly, we may have hidden strengths that are not complimented by our surroundings. Change your circumstances and try new things so that you can find your true capabilities.  4. Hire a specialist.  Most people want to wear their self-awareness on their sleeve. They speak the self-help lingo, read self-help books, talk about their spirituality, and have yet to work through their deepest issues. By surrounding themselves with positivity, they cover their challenges with a blanket of self development frou-frou. The people that are actually self-aware don’t have to brag about it, they just meet with their therapist on a consistent basis. If you’re serious about knowing your strengths and weaknesses, then work with a professional who can help you grow and mature as a person.  Most people give up their pursuit of self growth. They assume that they know all about themselves and are comfortable relaxing rather than putting in the time and effort needed to continue growing. Stagnant, they find a laundry list of excuses, and then spend the majority of their days complaining about their life circumstances.  Don’t be that type of person. Challenge yourself to continue learning and growing so that you can live a happy and fulfilling life. Reflect, ask for feedback, try new things,and hire a professional so that you can work through your weaknesses and amplify your strengths. Increase your self-awareness and achieve your potential.  -------------------- Matthew Jones writes at presencepowerpotential.com, where he shares an integrated approach to wellness and self-fulfillment that’s focused on balancing the mind, body, and spirit.  Follow Matt on Snapchat and Twitter: M_tthewJones

Many of us feel what we do the most, the best is our strength. I believe maybe yes, if we are talking about skills but otherwise, NO. I’d like to proceed talking about strengths and weakness on nature/ behavioural basis.(It is very easy to strengthen yourself in terms of skills and equally difficult in terms of behaviour and nature.Behaviour is the resultant of nature of a person (in majority) plus circumstance. This means there can be slight difference in behaviour as per circumstances but it is not the same with nature.) Your greatest strength is your weakness - anonymous To explain.. If you are a great talker, you talk too much. Listen more.(I didn’t say,great speaker)If you are a great listener, you listen too much. Talk more.(Sharing multiplies knowledge)If you are great at execution, you rely too much on getting things done. Dream more.(You’re a human, not machine)If you are a detail person, you’re rigid. Adapt more.(Rigidity might destroy you)If you are more professional, you’re work oriented. Enjoy personal life more.(Have a balance)Some qualities (core values) are such which don’t have labels of good/best or bad/worse.. either you have it or you just do not have it. For example : Consistency - either you are consistent or inconsistent, there is no good/bad consistency.Integrity - either you are a person with integrity or disintegrity, there is no good/bad in itCourage - either you are courageous or not courageous, there is no less or more in it.Loyalty - either you are loyal or you’re not loyal, there is no less or more in it.Honesty - either you are honest or dishonest, there exists no less or more honest. (One may read ‘ My Experiments with Truth ’ for better understanding of core values)Experiences along with self introspection can only help you know your strengths and weaknesses. Consider multiple experiences from your life and find the common traits, they will be your true strengths and weaknesses. Thank you for reading :) Image source : Google images.

People tend to dramatize their weaknesses and they’ll often try to do what they aren’t good at because it haunts them. Their attention gets stuck on it because they so desperately want to handle it. I did business with this guy years ago and he always talked about “ethics” and was always trying to push ethics on other people and frequently talked about it in a righteous manner. Later we found out that this guy had transgressions personally with a female colleague and financially in his business. I’ve come across people who’ve been terrible at certain areas of business and that’s the thing that they consistently get pulled toward and talk about the most. For me, I’ve always struggled with focus and it’s something I tend to think about and talk about a lot over the years and something I’m constantly working to improve. My message to you is this, before projecting on others or pointing fingers at others about something you have your attention on, first check yourself to verify that the thing you’re trying to put on others isn’t something that’s actually more intimately affecting you and that you personally have work to do to fix. Because that’s the thing I’ve noticed; the thing you’re weak on and compelled to get better at, that consumes your attention, you tend to project on others to try to get them to handle when you’re the one that either needs to handle it or move your attention to your strengths and find others who are strong in those areas and can support that side of the company to offset it. So if you find yourself stressing and projecting on other people a specific thing, take a second to look at yourself. Challenge yourself and say — where I am not doing this? Where am I not strong on this point? How am I weak on this? Then start there and work to solve that first by either fixing it yourself or finding others who are strong on that thing and have them help support the company so you can focus on your strengths. It’s important to know where you’re strong and where you’re weak and a clear indicator is the thing that consumes your attention and constantly seems to come up for you, is probably the thing that you’re weak on.

Reflect - What is it you have been told in the past that you have done very well? Write down everything you have liked to do and everything you did not like to do. Reflect on these things as often as you can, but at least once per week. Your strengths and weaknesses change constantly so keep track of them by reflecting upon them. Ask friends - Most often your closest friends know what you are good at, or what you like to do. Even if solely based on the way you talk about it or how you interact with others in certain situations. We all have a certain image of ourselves in our heads that is different to how others perceive us. Ask others for their honest opinions in both strengths and weaknesses without taking them too personally. Meditate - The point of meditation as a whole is to look within and to find out more about yourself. Take an hour out of your day and just sit with yourself and the question and see what comes up. We go about our lives in such a frantic way that we never talk to ourselves and find out more about who we are. Take some time and get to know the person you spend 24 hours every day with. Look for what you want to do - Even though you may not be good at it yet, the things you like to do are often those in which you develop your greatest strengths, simply because you will invest the most time in it. Everyone has natural talents, but those only account for a very minute part of your strenghts and weaknesses. If you find out what you like you will find out what you will grow most rapidly in. Opposite the two - Instead of asking “What are my strengths/weaknesses?” ask “What are not strengths/weaknesses of mine?”. Right now you want to identify your strengths and weaknesses and if you cannot do that by finding out directly then start eliminating that which it is not. This may be a longer process but it will get you closer nonetheless.

Thinking about your strengths and weaknesses as separate affects your ability to understand yourself. You strengths and your weaknesses are one and the same. Here is an example. I recently worked with a wonderful, intelligent, ambitious woman who found she was having trouble getting ahead. She was involved, driven, action oriented and open to feedback. The type of person who “gets things done”. If our strengths are also our weaknesses, can we take a look at the price her motivation comes with? What are the disadvantages of a singular focus on getting things done? She is always managing high levels of stress. I encourage her to take a breath, to intentionally let some time go by (sometimes an extra minute, sometimes a night) between a thought and her reaction to the thought. This, compounded, will result in less anxiety, less mental frenzy, added clarity and focus; and also in action that is more deliberate and thought-through. I suggest she take the time to read others. If her focus is getting things done, she is thinking of what to say or do while the other person (often her manager) is still talking. Can we listen without any other intent? If we cannot, what are we missing? What about collaboration? Action oriented people have a tendency to be faster, more efficient than others, and as such often resolve to act alone. “This will be easier if I just get it done”. But, this often means we sacrifice what we might learn from others. Fact: our way is not always the best way. Collaboration might compromise speed and might not come naturally, but it arrives with other benefits, one of which is increased self-awareness. The same applies to our ability to delegate. “For this to get done right, I have to do it” is the sign of a bad manager. It means we impair others and affect our own ability to scale. Delegation means growth: for others and for ourselves. The most important thing we can learn from this strength/weakness perspective is that it’s not supposed to be this hard. Feeling like we need to react quickly, like there is no time, like we can’t take a second to assess what another is going through, like everything has to get done by me and only me, is exhausting, isolating, unsustainable. Learning more about ourselves is about suffering less.

Late night dinner with my bestie. Sex and the city dress code. Wine, because wine not? I’ve called her and set in up in heart beat. She was sure a had a new scoop, a juicy gossip or life changing event I want to celebrate. I was waiting at the table with 2 sheets of paper. One for her, one for me. I was in a troubled time in my life and needed a little help. I already did the heavy emotional lifting on my own, but sometimes you want to have someone by your side. I handed her the piece of paper and asked her to do me favor and lay down her raw, unfiltered thought about me. Categories: best quality, biggest weakness, what you admire the most, what drives you crazy, what needs improvement and what I needed to let go. I did the same for her, on my sheet of paper. She needed help with what era to focus her efforts on. We laughed, we cried and cursed like sailors. Laughed again. Personal audits are though. You have to play good cop/bad cop with yourself and still feel like you’re winning in the end. Deep down, we all know our strengths and especially our weakness, but we can never have the big picture and know how those come across for other people. How they are perceived or how they affect the ones we love. Changing the perspective, switching it up for a more comprehensive view will help you improve and build up confidence as well. You’ll see that your flaws are not the end of the world and people might actually love you for them, and not despite of them. The most important takeaway is that personal growth is a process. It takes time. Accepting yourself as a whole, the good, the bad, the ugly, will take you closer to your end goal: becoming the best version of yourself and not just answering this strengths/weaknesses question at your next interview. Having a clear image will help you improve, change and love yourself more!

On the 25th of September 2014 I received an email with the subject line: “You’ve received a gift from Tai Lopez!” It was the audiobook of Managing Oneself by Peter Drucker.  Back then, you could sign up for his program for a $5 flat fee and got the book on top. Boy was that a good decision. I listened to the audiobook the next day on my drive home (it’s just 45 minutes long). I have never learned more about myself than in those 45 minutes. Drucker walks you through the questions all knowledge workers (and today we’re all knowledge workers) have to ask to succeed: Who am I?What are my strengths?How do I work?Where do I belong?What is my contribution?To find out your strengths, he suggests to use feedback analysis. Here’s how he describes this method: Whenever you make a key decision or take a key action, write down what you expect will happen. Nine or 12 months later, compare the actual results with your expectations. I have been practicing this method for 15 to 20 years now, and every time I do it, I am surprised. […] Practiced consistently, this simple method will show you within a fairly short period of time, maybe two or three years, where your strengths lie-and this is the most important thing to know. Several implications for action follow from feedback analysis. First and foremost, concentrate on your strengths. Put yourself where your strengths can produce results. Second, work on improving your strengths. Analysis will rapidly show where you need to improve skills or acquire new ones. Third, discover where your intellectual arrogance is causing disabling ignorance and overcome it. Other questions Drucker addresses in the book to help you cultivate self-awareness are: Am I a reader or a listener?How do I learn?Do I work well with people, or am I a loner?In what relationship do I work well with people?Do I produce results as a decision maker or an adviser?What are my values?What kind of person do I want to see when I look in the mirror in the morning?What should I contribute?Where and how can I have results that make a difference?This book helped me set myself on the trajectory I’ve been on for the past 2.5 years. But it was just the first step on a long staircase. I try to take the next step every day.  (stairs in Japan I saw while traveling in 2013) Some other tests, quizzes and resources that have helped me become more self-aware since then are: The OLD test (Obsessive Learning Disorder)Strengthsfinder 2.0The Habit Tendency QuizThe Jung Typology TestThe Learning Style QuizThe Bad Habit Breaker QuizSelf-awareness is the fuel of success. Without it, you’ll be swinging the bat on the wrong side of the field. Or worse, on the wrong field altogether. I hope you’ll find it faster than me. But to do that, one day you’ll have to start looking. Make today that day.  I write more here.

Business author Peter Drucker said, “A person can perform only from strength. One cannot build performance on weakness, let alone on something one cannot do at all.” Invest your time and energy into anything that pushes you towards the top of the mountain rather than away from it. That starts with keeping track of what you did and the results. The writer notes his or her word-count, the weightlifter their lifts and the runner miles on the track or road. Similarly, the sales executives tracks their calls or client meetings and the trader his or her positions. Identifying a strength gives you an opportunity to build on it. Repetition build competency. Competency leads to success. But what should you do after identifying a weakness? Perhaps you find writing really difficult, loathe public speaking or find busy rooms draining? Or perhaps you just hate jogging? Well, if you’re an introvert, perfecting your ability to work a room isn’t a great use of time. Similarly, if you’re an extrovert, you’re probably not going to enjoy long periods of quiet reflection. When you find a weakness, compensate for it by enlisting the help of someone else who cites that activity as a strength. Consider the CEO who relies on his or her chief operating offer to make the trains run on time their company. That COO frees the CEO to lead rather than get mired in the details. I once met an entrepreneur who specalised in connecting like-minded entrepreneurs with each other. Investors. CEOs. Public speakers. Authors. Those kinds of people. However, he struggled with the logistics of running a business, like admin, finances and finding new clients. So he partnered up with a friend who delights in the details but shies away from networking. Caution: a strength can become a weakness. Elon Musk loves telling the public all about his ambitious goals like colonising Mars or selling affordable electric cars to the masses. Capturing people’s attention is his strength but his promises don’t always translate into projects shipped on time. In other words, he can overpromise and under-deliver (a weakness) The same principles can work in your personal life. Or at least, they do in mine. I’ll happily spend hundreds of dollars hiring someone to complete projects around the house because DIY is a weakness. I can also focus on a single project, like writing a book chapter for a few hours, without getting distracted. That strength turns into a weakness whereby I focus too much on one project to the exclusion of everything else around me. My wife once complained, “You’re obsessed” when I said I’d spend the afternoon editing a troublesome article than outside in the sun. I knew my strengths. She knew my weaknesses.

Strengths I see the world from a scientific standpoint. It’s quite a task to fool me as I’m aware of Ponzi schemes, laws of nature and various conspiracy theories. To know how the world works is to know when you are most likely to being lied to.I’m loyal to those I love. Finding sincere people is is extremely hard so I appreciate those I have around me.My significant other told me that I always expect the best from people. If you have read my answers here on Quora, you might disagree, but in real life if someone asks for my help, I can almost never refuse. I consider this a good trait, because I personally like it if people are willing to help me in this rare occasion when I ask for it.I highly respect older people, even if they belong to “lower” class in the eyes of society. They have personally seen some stuff I can never even hope to witness myself. I don’t always agree with them, but they have taught me a lot.I see personality first, then appearance. It has shaped my life in the better direction.I see myself as an eternal student. Not because I delayed my university graduation for some years, but because I always see something new to learn. I will never be the master and I love it.I’m an introvert. Instead of following the path of popularity and fame, I have created some neat stuff in my lair. Instead of going out every weekend and getting wasted, I have discovered philosophy and the magic of knowledge.I have my own path and moral code. I don’t follow the rules 100% as I’m expected to.I was so pumped up by positive energy that I don’t want to provide any weaknesses anymore, but nobody is complete without any flaws so here they come.  Weaknesses The gates of my castle are closed by default, so it’s hard for me to reach out to other people having a fun picnic over the other side of the moat. Also, it’s a difficult task to earn my trust.My filter settings are set to extremely low, thus sometimes I’m too honest even when inappropriate. Also, I have no taboos.I’m constantly spacing out thinking about the plot of my sci-fi series. That’s why I tend to function inefficiently in our society and forget even simple daily chores.Pessimism. I’m always ready for the worst scenario and my daily thought process reflects it.Sarcasm and irony. If I’m in an extremely bad mood and I see something that I consider dumb, I tend to vent “indirectly”, sometimes the victim being totally oblivious of the cannon fire they just received (Philosophical war question: does firing non-damaging cannons have any point at all?).I find it hard to adapt to our modern life. I’m not even 30, but I feel like soon I will resemble that old grumpy gardener over there, who shouts “Get off the lawn, damn kids!”. The kids are like alien technology such as Instagram, Twitter and mumble rap. The lawn surrounding my moat is the last buffer zone separating my darlings from the things I don’t understand. I would be lost without retro, disco, rock’n’roll, boxy cars, Roman Empire and all the fascinating history and its outdated values. I’m always ready for the last battle as I said before - I’m loyal to those I love. Metaphorically speaking - will I survive the year 1453?

I am an Advocate. Confusing? Some time ago, I received a message on Quora regarding my personality. They said they think I am an INFJ personality type. Before even looking into it, I did a test on a personality website. Out of curiosity. I recommend doing it if you're interested and have a lot of spare time. Free personality test | 16Personalities (If you want to do the test though, do it before learning about the personality types.) And yep, that was the answer. Honestly I was surprised by how accurate it was. But then, by the end of the test, it had been written that I don't have to be surprised simply because I felt understood as they spent years on the research itself. It really helped me see my good side and my bad side. Here are INFJ personality type's strengths according to the site : They use their creativity to solve problems that seem real in the human world.Advocates are passionate about what they do. So the determination comes with their passion. Most often, Advocates are fighting for a cause they think is important.They prefer honesty. They use their insight to look past lies or dishonesty and to understand issues better.Apparently, Advocates have an inspirational, humane way of writing. If it's something they are interested in talking about, they may also have a convincing way of speaking.Advocates tend to follow through their plans until the end if it's something they consider important. Their decision making involves a lot of thought. They are good decision-makers.They believe in making this world a better place. Contributing to humanity is one of their biggest purposes in life. For that, they even come forth with their plans and ideas carried by strong beliefs.They choose quality over quantity when it comes to friendships. They look for authenticity, similar ideologies, comfort and potential growth (for themselves) when it comes to friendships. They are very loyal and supportive as friends.Quality over quantity in relationships too. When it comes to relationships, they want it to be authentic, meaningful and compatible. They need to feel a connection. When they have found the right person, their level of depth and sincerity reaches what most people can only dream of.They give their all when it comes to love. They commit fully. And they love endlessly.People with INFJ personality type are not compromising when it comes to their devotion for their children. They encourage their children to be independent, responsible, well-mannered and to form their own beliefs. Still they would like to see their children to be able to differentiate between what’s right and wrong and would like to see them contribute to the world in a way or two.Yes weaknesses exist too. And here are some : They are sensitive and usually not ready for arguments. They often get hurt if their ‘strong’ beliefs are criticized in some way.Advocates are perfectionists. However, in the real world, situations are far from perfect. They always believe in a “better” option and overlook healthy decisions or situations.If their beliefs aren’t kept in balance with the reality, they are most likely to exhaust themselves.Their passion comes with a cause. And so often, they are disappointed and lose their motivation if they don’t see a cause.Privacy is very important to Advocates; it’s important to the point that it keeps them from opening up to even their closest friends and family members.They are picky when it comes to relationships and friendships. Acts like lying, trying to talk them into something they don’t want, blaming them without expressing one’s concerns and not putting two-sided efforts are usually not forgiven.Because of that, they spend a lot of their time trying to find the right partner and right friends. And sometimes they are left with none.Advocates are scared to commit because of their tendency to love endlessly, and because of their sensitivity in issues. Small things matter to them.Advocates tend to force their beliefs (the ones they deem as right) on their children. They like to see a lot of their qualities on their children and sometimes they go to extents to make that happen.They have a hard time choosing a career path because of their beliefs. They see so many different paths. And often question themselves.Famous people with this personality type : Nelson Mandela, Martin Luther King, Mother Teresa, Jimmy Carter and Morgan Freeman.

[1] Being able to identify your strengths and weaknesses is vitally important when you are on a self improvement journey or want to achieve your goals. However there is a problem; it is very difficult for a lot of people to identify their strengths and weaknesses. We often underestimate how good we are at some things and overestimate the thing's we're not particularly good at. It takes a lot of self awareness to be able to accurately evaluate your strengths and weaknesses. Becoming more self aware is a good place to start and can be incredibly useful for life in general.   I have come up with a method I often use myself that gives me exactly what you are looking for. I started by not focusing on my strengths or weaknesses. I focussed on my achievements and failures. I found it easier to identify those thing's. I think you will too. List your successes and list your failures, then next to each success and each failure, write what strengths are needed to achieve them. You should begin to find a pattern. Your strengths should consistently show up on your successes and your weaknesses will consistently show up on your failures. When you've done this, congratulations, you've found what you are looking for. Then you can start working on improving on the weaknesses you feel are particularly important to you and your future. Footnotes[1] Identifying Your Business’ Strengths and Weaknesses

There is a whole set of very good books out there, using the method called the “strengthfinder” approach as pioneered by Tom Rath (strengthfinders 2.0) and Marcus Buckingham (Standout 2.0). They ask you to assess a fundamental question to identify whether your current role taps into your natural strengths: to what extent do you agree with this statement? “My job gives me the opportunity to do what I do best every day.“ It’s a really good question to ponder. I have a slightly different and complementary take on this. Here’s my rationale, and a good assessment for you. In my study, we identified 7 key work practices that predicted two-thirds of the difference in performance among the 5,000 people in our study. Other things matter too, of course, such as your natural talent, experience and luck, among other things. These 7 practices seem really important. Given that, the question becomes, how do you currently stack up against those seven? Which are you currently doing pretty well, and which ones not? Armed with that information, you can choose what to focus on to improve your work practices. The management experts behind the strengthfinder approach advocate that you keep improving on your strengths, and that makes sense in their use of the term. In my approach, I would go for the “weakest link”: pinpoint which of the seven is your weakest part yet key in your job. For example, say you score low on the practices of “fight and unite,” which sometimes is called “disagree and commit.” This involves speaking up and generating a rigorous debate in meetings to let the best arguments and ideas emerge and prevail. Now, if you don’t run or participate in such meetings in your job, you wouldn’t pick this one. But if you do and your score is low, it’s a good place to start developing your skills. So how do you find out? It’s of course a process of some assessment and introspection. To get you started, I have developed a brief assessment of 20 questions that let you benchmark yourself against our sample of 5,000 managers and employees (it’s an abbreviated version of the lengthy survey instrument we used). Here’s the link: https://www.mortenhansen.com/quiz/

Keep it light, jovial. Your strengths and your weakness are the same thing in different contexts: in one sense you know what you're doing and are confident, while in another you are too confident and something sneaks past you. This is a navel-gazing question, and if you go too deep with it, you will pull everybody else in the conversation into the deep end and make them work too hard. So, it's kind of a trap. In a personal conversation, make things up. “I'm a really good swimmer, but if I get the teeniest amount of water?? Man, I can't think straight for the vertigo it causes.” Or, “I can sleep anywhere, but I'm afraid of the dark.” “I can't touch or eat foods that are temperature-hot, but I can eat consecutive ghost chilies…” that last one is a great example of why you should make what you say nonsense or reasonable to accomplish, should it backfire. If this is for an interview, then the interviewer is motivated for any number of reasons to ask you this question: Are you a good fit for the company? Are you capable of sounding authentic? How well do you understand and speak of yourself? How well do you prepare for questions? Again, be less revealing and more accommodating — “I think my weakness and my strength both come from recognizing I can't do everything on my own. This helps me to focus as a team player on learning how my co-workers operate and seek how we can cooperate to be more effective.” If you are a lone wolf, however, and you use this — I recuse myself of all responsibility.
