You've got to come up with an answer that works for you…but lighter and less serious seems to score on this point.

The short answer is that a strength is something that makes you and your life better. A weakness is something that makes you or your life less happy or more difficult. Using myself as an example when I was young I decided one of my weaknesses was my trusting nature. After having decided that was a weakness I then had to decide what to do about it. I certainly didn’t want to be a distrustful scrooge but I also didn’t want to naive. Time and maturity took care of some of the problem and with that I learned how best to deal with the kind of person who prays on those who are by nature, trusting. So what gets you into trouble? Analyze that and ask yourself, is this connected to a weakness that you can work on to better yourself? As for strengths, sometimes they hide in what you may think of as weakness. Again let me use myself as an example. After 58 years of life I can say without a doubt what I do best is taking care of others. I tried to fight it when I was young but it’s what I am. Nurturers often have a hard time learning to say no to people (another weakness). Learning to say “NO” however is something a “Nurturer” has to learn not only in self defense but because it is not healthy for the “Nurturer” or those we care for, for us to always say “Yes”. My strength, “Nurturing” would become a weakness if I did not know when to say, “NO”. Understanding that I feel is another strength. I hope this helps. Good luck finding your strengths and weaknesses, it is a quest of a lifetime.

Knowing your own emotional triggers from your childhood are very important. The chip on your shoulder is what will drive much of your decision making, because your brain rewards you for satisfying those chips. There are three paths: You prioritize political power / economic security, because you were either bullied or ostracized in your youth, or came from a working-class background, you will naturally choose that path.You prioritize building community, a vibrant social life, fame, influence or notoriety, because your childhood rewarded you with lots of external validation from your primary school peers, you will naturally choose this path.You prioritize authenticity, craftsmanship, or working with things, because you had a very reserved, quiet, but deep & rich inner life of experimentation & creativity, you’ll naturally choose this path.The thing is - money is only a number. After making money, those chips are the garden you need to tend to, because they are what will build a lot of anxiety unless you address it. Choosing to optimize on addressing that anxiety (it’s part of your mental health), and finding the career / lifestyle that addresses it is the best path to take, for each individual. Derick Sivers outlined this well, in his article: Why are you doing?. We can only choose one: fame, freedom / lifestyle, money, power, learning. Trying to optimize on all will only dilute your strengths. A more accurate litmus test is: “Which type of beach town will you retire at?” - it’ll review much more about your personality, more than what you do for a living.

Many leaders would rather eat a bug than admit to others they made a mistake or expose a weakness. Exposing your own failures is not a sign of weakness. Hiding your failures is! Nobody believes we are perfect. In fact, when we own up to our own weaknesses, we are rarely telling them anything they don’t already know.  It is counter-cultural among leaders to point out their own short-comings. We seem to feel if we expose a weakness, then they will think less of us. Or, they might not trust us because we have exposed our soft white underbelly to others. The decision to not expose our past mistakes and current short-comings actually accomplishes exactly what we are trying to avoid. When we hide our frailties from people who already know what they are, we lose our chance of gaining the respect, the trust and the allegiance of the people we are supposed to be leading. When we admit our frailties to people who already know what those frailties are, what we gain is respect. We gain trust. We gain allies. Exposing your weaknesses actually attracts followers. Why Do Leaders Hide Their Failures Why do we avoid exposing our failures to others? There is only one real answer – PRIDE. When you never admit to your failures or weaknesses, you absolve yourself of any responsibility for growing beyond the person you already are. A leader who is not growing is a leader who is losing ground and will eventually lose the people he desires to have following him. An interesting thing happens when you swallow your pride and begin to expose your weaknesses and failures to others – you begin to take ownership of them. You begin to grow and gain from others what you were afraid of losing – respect, trust, and allegiance. The Bottom Line Breaking the cycle of pride and developing the Habit of Character called Humility takes practice. Humility is like a muscle, you have to exercise it regularly or it will never gain strength. On the other hand, if you exercise pride, it will become a dominant habit in your character. What are some simple exercises a leader can do to develop Humility to the point it is stronger than our pride? Here are a few for your consideration: Humility Exercises Report your failures to your supervisor, your employees, your spouse, or your children. Don’t wait for them to discover them.Tell your team you are not good at a particular aspect of your job, and ask someone to help you.Apologize after losing your temper at work or at home.If you screw up, admit it and share with others how you are going to fix it.Laugh when you do something embarrassing instead of hiding it, running from it, or getting angry about it.By exposing your weaknesses and failures to others, you strengthen your character. You strengthen your Humility. You strengthen the bonds of respect, trust, and allegiance that both the leader and the led want and need desperately. Source: www.andersonleadershipsolutions.com

For me, it doesn't make sense to try to analyze strengths and weaknesses without a context. You can develop a general list of strong or weak points but unless you have a goal in mind they don't really mean anything. For instance your strengths and weaknesses in considering a career field will be different for each choice. Say are a great driver but the career you are considering has you at only one location all day. While driving may be a strength it doesn't really matter because it doesn't play into the plan for your career. The second reason I say have a context is so that you can follow your heart. I've seen the results of people who listed what they thought were their strengths and then said “what can I do that matches that?” They can have nice, stable, boring careers and make a good living but it can turn miserable and usually does. Instead start from the context of what you would like to do. List the strengths that make people successful doing that and then rate how strong you are in each of the areas. Take a long hard look at the gap between your current capabilities and the successful state and decide if you are willing to pay the price in discipline and work to bridge those gaps. This approach will rarely tell you you can't do something and can help you formulate a plan for success if you honestly decide you should go for it. Don't make a major long term decision without going over what you have worked out with one or two people who know you well. We all have blind spots to both our positive and negative capabilities. When you get feedback don't react, think long on it and and then decide on whether to act on your plan, amend it, or start over.

Talk to a few people that you admire and feel are intelligent, honest and know you well personally and/or professionally. The longer they have known you, the better. Tell them that you want their help and to give you their assessment of your strengths (and weaknesses; why not?).   Ask them for the brutal truth.   We often perceive ourselves differently than others do. Our perception is our reality, though. It's very interesting to hear what other's have to say . Prepare yourself emotionally to hear anything, but  I have found this to be a very helpful exercise. Use the feedback you receive, both positive and negative, to provide clarity to your own self-understanding.  Empower yourself to build on your strengths and continue to improve. BTW, I found some excellent answers in this very similar question to yours:https://www.quora.com/How-can-someone-accurately-identify-personal-strengths-and-weaknesses

This requires being able to perceive where you excel.  Just b/c you excel in an area does not necessarily mean that you have to utilize that strength if it doesn't appeal to you.  For example, I am fairly strong in the kitchen -- I'm the type who doesn't have to follow a recipe and likes to experiment and most of the time my creations receive compliments.  However, I never once considered becoming a professional chef b/c my main interest is computer programming.   So, while it's good to be aware of your strengths, you need to also be aware of what you like.  It's much easier to handle an activity if you want to be there as opposed to simply being good at it.

Knowing your weaknesses and strengths is not rocket science if you are always watching yourself. To make this easier for you, begin with creating a list of your weaknesses and strengths. Take a piece of paper and divide it into two columns. On one column write your strengths and the other your weaknesses. However, this is not yet a surefire way of knowing yourself since we tend to be biased with the opinions we have of ourselves. You want to talk to people you trust and have been over your life for some time. It could be a friend, colleague, or schoolmate. Also, try new things. Dancing, singing, public speaking, or running. These activities may help you identify what you are good at and what you are not. If all fails, you may want to pay for a personality test and get to know about your strengths and weaknesses from a proven system.

Focus on options you did not follow. There might have been better solutions but were missed. Reasons of missing should be written. Regular diary-writing should continue. Important events be noted separately on a yearly basis (on separate sheet, if necessary). Learn SWOT analysis technique. Work on yourself before starting an assignment/task. See where are the voids. Through experience of course, as time goes by you realize that there are things that never bother you, which you can do without putting a lot of effort and without being exhausted about it… Once done, you rarely need to refine and review it in terms of appropriatenss… Those are your strengths… Weaknesses are quite easier to spot as anything you find difficult to complet despite having ample encounters will be considered a weakness… P.S. do not fall prey to this kind of question in a job interviews… It's a way for them to psychologically remind you of your own perceived weaknesses so always describe your strengths as your weaknesses such as “my biggest weakness is that I do not tolerate incomplete tasks” or “in this cruel world me trying to be a good guy is my biggest weakness” they wanna take it to you, Take the war to their grounds…

strength: being able to compartmentalize my thoughts/feelings examples—1. i have a farm where i raise my own food. every animal gets named. i love them all & treat them well for the time i have them. the first bull i raised for meat was named “Dinner.” some of the roosters got names like “Crock Pot” or “Nugget.” Pet/breeders got more normal names like Buckley, Baby Girl, etc. It helps keep things in perspective. 2. in a previous career (public service), i had to deal with people from all walks of life & various attitudes; rarely did i see these people at their best. they could call me names, or worse, but when it came down to it & they needed something, i could be there for them & not hold their previous actions against them. it really worked in my favor. there were many times that i was able to diffuse situations just by talking to them because they came to realize that i was not one to spout bs & could actually be counted on to be “real” & tell them the truth. weakness: sometimes i feel too much (emotional? sentimental?) example—i don’t watch chick-flicks because hollywood’s version of romance is sooo sappy. i will cry at the drop of a hat. then i remember that it’s only a movie. i may have to give up wholesome shows/movies, too; i’ve recently been watching “Little Men” & i’ll be danged if I haven’t cried during quite a few of them as well! Give me a good comedy or mystery, and i’m good.

I am sure anyone can answer the strengths even though not perfect. Because all you need to do is relate your skills, your achievements, your education to the job description and role and showcase your strong skills and how you are perfect fit to the position being interviewed. I am sure anyone can support greatest strengths, but answering greatest weaknesses is tough. It can cost you the job. What is your greatest weakness? Most career books tell you to select a strength and present it as a weakness. Such as: "I work too much. I just work and work and work." Wrong. First of all, using a strength and presenting it as a weakness is deceiving. Second, it misses the point of the question. You should select a weakness that you have been actively working to overcome. For example: "I have had trouble in the past with planning and prioritization. However, I'm now taking steps to correct this. I just started a planner app on my mobile to better plan and prioritize…" then pull out your mobile to show how you are using the app. Talk about a true weakness and show what you are doing to overcome it. Good Luck!!!

Ask you friends and then ask yourself what they like/dislike about you. This is the easiest and requires the least amount of effort. If you want to dig deeper, then recollect those moments when you were happy high or really down. These moments represent the situations which make you Excel or succumb (become submissive). Once both of these exercises are done you know what people like/dislike and what you like/dislike. E.g say I was very happy getting selected for an scholarship. That could mean I strength is hard work and diligence and it could also mean that I love appreciation because of which I can do great feats. Identify which one has a greater pull by looking back at more instances where one of the 2 played out. And you will have your answer. Being truthful if also important if you are doing this for self good. If you are doing this for an interview say anything that the crowd likes.

If you want to really find out what you are made of (what your strengths and weaknesses are), then you need to put yourself in situations that contain a high degree of “outcome uncertainty”. Outcome uncertainty occurs when you take on a task/process that is unknown to you, prone to mistakes, and will likely result in failure. Examples are: Starting a company.Speaking in front of a large group.Competitions (sports, arts, etc).Publishing (book, blog, etc).When you make a mistake and fail, you learn the most about yourself and what you are made of. Successful people take these lessons and work on their strengths and weaknesses so that the likelihood of success increases in the future. I know it sounds simple, but it is true.

See, the same thing which can be strength, can also be the weakness, and vice versa.  Anything which is below the particular desirable limit, is a weakness, and in the same way anything which is above the particular desirable limit, is also a weakness. So that's the point. So everything should be under the desirable limit, to be strength. But I said that the same thing which can be strength, can also be the weakness, so can I replace weakness with strength and vice versa, in above paragraph? Well, yes, thats also will be correct, but, the above paragraph is more correct, for general purposes and goals, however the right opposite of it can also be correct, for a particular purposes and goals. So the qualities one have, is only about more or less correct as per the desired goals, its not about whether the qualities are strengths or weakness, as it depends upon the goal to be achieved. So, a quality, could be a weakness for achieving one goal, and could be a strength for achieving another goal.  For example, there are two sides of a work, one is related to thinking, and another is related to practicality i.e. one side needs thoughtfulness, and another side needs being practical. Every work need some degree of thoughtfulness, and some degree of practicality, and not all work has same proportion of thoughtfulness to practicality. Every work has varying degree of both, some work demands more practicality than thoughtfulness, and some requires more thoughtfulness than practicality. You know that both these qualities are actually strengths, and desirable, but both these, are kind of inversely proportional to each other i.e. if thoughtfulness will be more, the practicality will be less, in proportion, and vice versa. That means you need to sacrifice some of one quality to gain some of other quality, or, whenever you try to gain some of one good quality, you will lose some of the other good quality, which means, though both good qualities are strengths, but trying to gain one will result in losing other in proportion. Thats the truth of it which is difficult to explain and understand, if you don't have an experience or mindset to take notice of that experience. So, if you think that you have weakness in one quality and trying to overcome that weakness, you have to sacrifice the another strength of you, which will be your next weakness. Take into the notice from above paragraph, that both the qualities above mentioned, that  one can have, is actually a strength, and, the thinking that someone thinks that he/she has one weakness in one of the quality, above mentioned as example, is his/her own thinking, because thinking something to be weakness/strength depends on what exactly your work and goal is, and also that one good quality is inversely proportional to other good quality, which means it is an individual who is wrong, who think a quality to be a weakness or strength. Quality of human is a "Quality", not a weakness or strength. A quality is a strength or weakness, depending upon the work you do or chose to do i.e. your goal, otherwise it is only a strength, if the work and goal is not considered, or rightly chosen as per your quality. So I would say all the qualities you have is a strength, and try to chose a goal as per your qualities, and don't consider your qualities as a weakness, depending upon your wrong goal. That's the idea behind the true education.  For more clarification, let's have my very own example I am over-thinking person, means I used to think a lot, and continuously think, think, and more think, and I enjoy thinking, and I almost always all the time lost in thinking about something, some problems, some questions, some solutions, some ideas, some philosophies. I find thoughts to be very beautiful, which I cannot quit, and also useful. However this quality of mine is still not at all productive except increased understanding, logicalness, explanatory capabilities, new ideas etc. but it is not at all productive in monetary terms, or making my life any good. Some people knows that over-thinking causes a kind of laziness, and perceived as being idle (I am working though, but my job is only to sit and enjoy), and not contributing much to others life. My over-thinking nature bestow me an ability to share my thoughts, as I am always in front of my computer, reading and writing, but because I am over-thinking person, I can less be a practical person, and that's psychology. My over-thinking and lost in thinking attitude makes me unable to do anything productive on monetary terms over the internet, on which I am being all the time throughout the day. Now you can perceive my over-thinking nature as a weakness, Right? Because you have attached my over-thinking attitude with some work, Right? Laziness is also not a strength, but it is a weakness, am I right? So do you think I need to quit over-thinking? Well, though it seems to be a weakness, I certainly know that this is my strength, and I certainly know, that for understanding, sharing thoughts, being logical, its very necessary to be over-thinking, and many many areas of the world requires over thinking attitudes, though they are very less, and rarely get notice, but I think those are the most important ones, as thinking precedes practice, no matter thinker don't practice its thoughts, generally. And quite frankly, those who are practical and do not think, generally practice thinking of some intellectual work of the other, thats for sure. So thinking is quite an important job in itself, and it requires free time, and mental processing. So what if I leave over-thinking and try to be practical, thinking that over-thinking is a weakness? Well, that way I will lose over-thinking attitude which is much important in some which requires deeper understanding with logical reasoning. What if I try to leave laziness, which is certainly perceived as weakness, but I know there is only two side of work, one of which is related to thinking, and one of which related to practicing. One which relates to thinking is generally perceived as weakness, like say, laziness, lack of concentration (as you need to change perspective for thinking, but focus on one for practicing), lack of memory (that is difficult to explain here), weird (thinker many times are foolish, that people generally don't like), bitter (truthful) slow learner (thinking requires you to be slow to understand. So there are two side of any work, thinking and practicing, and the qualities related to thinking side is generally perceived as weakness, though it is not, and those qualities are not required generally, but very specifically and rarely.  In the same way, qualities related to practicalness is perceived as strengths, and they are, of course, but generally. Actually you only have strengths, and you need to find a proper thing which requires your qualities to be considered or perceived as strengths. So I would say, don't judge yourself by the ability of climbing a tree, when you are a fish. I think, if you can read this comment again, it will certainly help you. Thank you. You try new things. Accept new challenges. Whether you succeed or fail, never stop observing yourself. For each skill/trait/core competency, make sure to set the average standard output, then compare your own output to it. If you’re above average, then it’s definitely a strength point, monitor it, sharpen it, it will benefit you in the future, however, if you leave it unattended, it will fade away and you’ll require to re-sharpen it again in the future if you’re ever to use it. If you’re below/within average, then it’s certainly a weakness point, at that point you’re going to have to make a choice; either pursue it in an attempt to improve, or leave it be and accept that it’s just not your thing. One thing you need to do is, never let your weakness get in the way of keeping your strength points; if you have 2 cars in your garage, one damaged and one working, this doesn’t mean you should drive the good one and leave the other one to rot, neither should you spend your entire time trying to fix the damaged one and forget that you already have another one that’s fully functional. Make sure both cars get their due diligence. Good Luck !

This is a difficult question that you might not necessarily have the self awareness to determine on your own. People’s strengths and weaknesses tend to be easily clustered into these 16 types, and from my experience and many others, it’s very accurate. There might be one or two strengths or weaknesses you may disagree with, and that’s totally fine. But it’s a great starting point to building self awareness.

Ask other people, and observe yourself. Then take a call, based on your actions historically, and also on gut feeling. Do not be hesitant, your instinct is powerful and important, do not ignore it. Other people should be a diverse set preferably, varied in gender, age, and demography, so that you can get a fair idea. People, till date, have lived a very localised life, so a strength, according to an Indian, can be a weakness in the Western World, and vice versa.  When you really look deep, you can see that your strengths are also your weaknesses! But, over here, I believe that you are looking for qualities in which you are better than others, vs in which you are not. That can be identified when you look at your past performance record. My only suggestion is not to delve too deep and make any judgment out of it, because the most important quality we have is the ability to change and evolve!

Question: What is the best way to find out my strengths and weaknesses? Answer: Talk to your real close friends, who you believe will give you honest opinions, not just say things we like to hear. Secondly, analyze your past successes and failures and if required talk about them also with your close friends. Be in a calm situation and unperturbed mind and do your own analysis as well. In the end, do your own analysis. Use all of the inputs from your friends but trust your instincts. Because no one other than your own self can chart your best path to success.

My greatest strength is my strong will, I don't run away from my problems, I don't quit when things get hard, and am tireless in my pursuit of the things I want. I don't lose control, and I don't panic in stressful situations. And my greatest weakness is my intractable stubborn streak. I don't quit when I'm over matched, and I treat everything as a challenge. I'm tireless in my pursuit of the things I want, even if it hurts me. I don't lose control, which makes people think me as emotionless, and I don't panic, which has unnerved people around me. People expect a certain level of emotion when your house burns down, or when you break bones, or when you hear of some tragedy, and it scares people when they see someone who doesn't react to any of that. So brave on one hand, so foolish on the other.

An entrepreneur sees opportunity where others don't. That is the one skill you need to learn to be a successful entrepreneur. Force yourself to imagine a new product or service every week. Do a quick business plan for it (with a spreadsheet of projections) and have someone shoot holes in it. Do that task over and over again and you'll learn the skills you need to be an entrepreneur. The people who are especially good at shooting holes in your weekly plans are the people who have the skills you lack. Instead of improving your weaknesses, widen your circle of friends / advisors / consultants and let them, not you, do what you are not so good at.  You'll eventually find a need that no one else is filling AND where your experts can't find a flaw. That's the business idea you devote more time to research. That's the business you have your experts help get it reviewed by their experts.

Anything that you can do is your strength. Not what you think you can do but that which you have already done in the past and would happily do again whenever required.  For example, you have asked this question. So, by my definition, asking questions is your strength. Corollary to this is anything that you can not do is your weakness. Not what you think you can not do but that which, when there was a need to do it, you shied away from and would happily do the same in future. Make no mistake about it, a strength is a strength, even if it is not exactly aligned with your current goal/s. Similarly, a weakness is a weakness, even if it is not currently coming in your way. I hope this has helped. Please feel free to ask your query/ies if any. I shall try my best to address them.

I have a somewhat good memory. To that end, I remember things easily, be it the good, the bad or the ugly. This is why I struggle with forgiveness, particularly when someone dear has wronged or embarrass me in public. I would then harbor not so pleasant, or maybe sometimes outright wicked thoughts; piercing myself with much agony in the process of plotting my revenge. On the other hand, when the same person suddenly does something kind in return, be it to make it up or simply sincerely, I would also remember their deeds. Even when the time is ripe for revenge, the left hand always seems to restrain the right hand as I remind myself of the good that the individual has also done for me. I then come to a bittersweet conclusion, in real life, the heroes are not always the heroes, the villains are not always the villains. Nobody is perfect.
